Category: Abbreviation of the main system shall be the prefix
The subsystem shall follow the prefix if it is used
Sample Use: In some cases the subsystem is not necessary and therefore not used

Category: The sensor or control device shall be the suffix
There shall be no space between the system/subsystem and the iteration of the equipment
Spaces shall separate abbreviations for readability
Where a sensor or control device measures or controls a common header from two or more systems, omission of the system/subsystem iteration number will designate a common sensor or control device
Sample Use: This example denotes the common supply water temperature sensor on the main header of multiple boilers

Category: 3 letter abbreviations are used as much as reasonably possible to maintain industry standard nomenclature
All capital letters will be used to designate I/O
Names are kept as short as reasonably possible so as to keep programming lines shorter, viewing columns narrower and sedondary objects more clear.
Secondary (non I/O) objects will iterate the I/O label at the beginning of their label followed by the descriptive text of the secondary object
Description: AHU1 SAT Setpoint, AHU1 FAN Status

Category: Secondary objects will use single capital letter followed by small letter for differentiation between a physical I/O object and a "virtual" object
Description: VAV7 RMT Heat Setpoint, VAV7 RMT Cool Setpoint, VAV7 Mode

Category: For certain secondary objects: TL, CO, BT, AT; the object name will be the name that the secondary object monitors followed by the object acronym of the object itself
Description: VAV7 RMT TL, VAV7 RMT CO, VAV7 RMT Heat Setpoint TL

Category: Objects will be in logical groupings according to the control loop
Description: AHU1 SAT Setpoint, AHU1 SAT, AHU1 SAT CO
Sample Use: Focus is on the control loop and associated variable rather than the device that modifies the variable.  In many cases multiple devices can temper the variable (for example with SAT a MAD, HCV, CCV, Humidifier, DX, LLS, UL, BAD, etc. are all possible control devices that may affect the variable).  This promotes clarity as to what the equipment is trying to achieve.
